journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Microstructure and finite element analysis of 3D five-directional braided composites

contrib-group.aff: 1Tianjin and Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Advanced Textile Composite Materials, Institute of Textile Composite, Tianjin Polytechnic University, Tianjin, China.
2Department of Textile Engineering, Henan Institute of Engineering, Zhengzhou, China.
3Division of Textiles and Clothing, Department of Biological & Agricultural Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA, USA.

author-notes.corresp: Li Chen, Key Laboratory of Advanced Textile Composites, Ministry of Education, Tianjin 300160, China Email: chenli@tjpu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Microstructure of 3D five-directional braided composites determines its mechanical properties. Microscopic evidence of the microstructure reveals that the cross-sections of the axial yarn are variable along its central axial due to the lateral compression from the adjacent braiding yarns. On the basis of microscopic observations, a dense but non-intersecting geometry internal unit cell model of 3D five-directional braided composites is established. By using the unti-cell model, a 3D mesomechanical FEA is proposed to predict the effective elastic properties of 3D five-directional braided composites. Compared with existing model, present model is more effective to calculate the mechanical properties of 3D five-directional braided composites with more than 50% fiber volume fraction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Three-dimensional braided composites have been widely applied in the aerospace, automobile, and marine industries due to its advantages, including through-thickness reinforcement, high damage tolerance, and near-net-shape manufacturing.1 In the past, considerable efforts have been made on the understanding of the microstructure2–5 and the mechanical properties6–8 of 3D four-directional braided composites.

Three-dimensional five-directional braided composites have been developed by introducing the axial reinforced yarns (fifth directional yarns) in the braiding direction based on the four-step braiding patterns. The mechanical properties of 3D braided composites, which are enhanced effectively in the braiding direction for the adding of the axial yarns, are especially suited for application in primary loading-bearing structures and received great attention recently. Wu9 firstly proposed a simple geometrical model to predict the mechanical properties of 3D five-directional braided composites based on the laminate theory. Li et al.10 established a topological model on the basis of the braiding process study, but the elliptical cross-section assumption of the axial yarns was far from the reality. Chen et al.11 and Li et al.12 studied the mechanical properties by experiments, which provided the basic data for the further research. Lu and Liu13 calculated the elastic properties of 3D five-directional braided composites by the stiffness volume-averaging method on the basis of the microstructure model presented by Wu.9 Recently, Chen and Xu9 analyzed the yarn’s arrangement and their section shape deformation in 3D five-directional braided composites based on the microscopic observations, which provided important experimental support for modeling microstructure exactly. Xu et al.15,16 and Li et al.17 both established a solid unit cell of 3D five-directional braided composites and calculated the elastic constants by FEA, but the cross-section shape of the axial yarns was inconsistent with the experimental observations, which made the model unable to be used to analyze high fiber volume fraction samples. Li et al.18 presented an analysis of the microstructure in 3D five-directional braided preforms and defined three distinct types of unit cell in the interior, surface, and corner regions, respectively. By using the three unit cell models, a micromechanical prediction procedure is described to simulate the mechanical properties of 3D five-directional braided composites.

The main objective of present work is to develop a new representative volume element (RVE) to describe the true microstructure of 3D five-directional braided composites. The effects of the cross-section shape deformation and the yarn pack factor on the construction of the microstructure model have been taken into consideration. Based on the unit cell model established, a 3D mesomechanical FEA is adopted to study the mechanical properties of composites. With the FEA method, the effective elastic properties will be predicted and obtained a good agreement with the experimental results.

sec.title: Microstructure analysis
sec.p: Mechanical properties of 3D braided composites are primarily determined by their topology. Similar to 3D four-directional braided preforms, the topological structure of 3D five-directional braided preforms is also determined by the braiding process, which is realized through the permutation of yarn carriers on a machine bed by row and column track movements in the x and y direction, respectively, and the preforms are fabricated in the z-direction. Different from 3D four-directional braiding, some axial yarn carriers are placed between the braiding yarn carriers in rows to introduce the axial yarns in the 3D five-directional braiding process. During one machine cycle of 3D five-directional braiding process, the movements of all the braiding yarn carriers are similar to those of the braiding yarn carriers in 3D four-directional braiding process. Four carrier movement steps accomplish in one machine cycle and each braiding yarn carrier moves one position at each step.4 Meanwhile, the axial yarn carriers do not move at the first and third steps, and move one position horizontally with the braiding yarn carriers at the second and fourth steps. After these four steps, the arrangement of yarn carriers on the machine bed return to the original pattern. Then a certain ‘jamming’ action is imposed on the yarns, which makes the yarns more closely intertwined. As these steps of motion continue, the braiding yarns move throughout the cross-section and interlace with the axial yarns to form a preform. The unit length of the resultant preform is defined as the braiding pitch length, denoted by h.

In order to ensure uniform braided structure, the braiding process is supposed to be steady, at least in a specified length of braiding. According to the movement of yarn carriers, the internal topological structure of 3D five-directional braided composites can be represented by the RVE, named as interior unit cell shown in Figure 1. In the unit cell, there are a group of axial yarns along the z-axis and four groups of braiding yarns oriented γ with the z-axis, where γ is defined as the interior braiding angle. The width and the thickness of the unit cell are denoted by Wi and Ti, respectively. The length of the unit cell is equal to the braiding pitch length h, where h = Wi/tanγ.19 Figure 1.
Topological structure of the preform.

sec.title: Limitation of Xu’s model
sec.p: Recently, Xu and Xu15 established a 3D finite element model to study the mechanical properties of 3D five-directional braided composites. The cross-section shape of the braiding yarns is assumed to be hexagonal and the cross-section shape of the axial yarns is square. According to the developed model, the fiber-volume fraction, which is one of the most important braiding parameter, can be rewritten as follows: (1) Where r is a size factor of the axial yarn and equals 3 in the model,15 and εa is the packing factor of the axial yarn.

Figure 2 shows the variation of the packing factor of axial yarns vs. the interior braiding angle and the fiber volume fraction. It indicates that the yarn packing factor is more than 0.9 in most cases, even more than 1. However, the extreme of yarn packing factor is 0.907 while the fibers in the yarn are jammed closely in hexagon.20 The main reason for inducing incorrect yarn packing factor is that an assumption of invariable cross-section was made for the axial yarns, which ignores the lateral deformation of the axial yarn pressed by the adjacent braiding yarns. Same problem is found in the model reported by literature.17 The yarn packing factor is a key parameter, which has a decisive effort on the prediction of the mechanical properties of composites. Therefore, it is necessary to pay more attention to improve it firstly. Figure 2.
Variations of the yarn packing factor of axial yarns versus the interior braiding angle in Xu’s model.

sec.title: Microscopic observations and new unit cell model
sec.p:
Optical microscope is employded to investigate the cross-section shape of the yarn in present study. A serial of cross-sections of 3D five-directional braided composites was choosen in a pitch length along the braiding direction, as shown in Figure 3. At each pointed positions, the rectangular specimen was cut off to get the cross-sections, and then polished enough to take digital photographs under a microscope. Eight cross-sections are obtained at an interval of 1/8 h. Figure 3.
Illustration of the section position of 3D five-directional braided composities.

Figure 4 shows four cross-sections in a pitch length obtained above. All the yarns used in braiding have the same component material, size and flexibility, while, the cross-section shapes are quite different in the final composites due to the mutual squeezing of the yarns. The micrographs reveal that the section shapes of the braiding yarns look like a ellipse with the major axis oriented approximatively on +45°or −45°, and the cross-sections of the axial yarns have variable shape in different planes due to the lateral compression of the braiding yarns in different directions. This distortion cannot be ignored in the structural and the mechanical analysis. Figure 4.
Cross-section of 3D five-directional braided composites in a pitch length.

There is an obvious interface between the axial yarn and the braiding yarn from the high power micrograph (Figure 5). Fibers in braiding and axial yarns have different cross-section shapes. Fibers with circular section belong to the axial yarn, while the fibers with elliptical section belong to braiding yarn. The fiber volume fraction of each region is calculated quantitatively by image processing as signed in Figure 5. It shows that the yarn packing factor of the axial yarn is approximately equivalent to that of the braiding yarn. Figure 5.
High power micrograph of the interface between the braiding yarn and the axial yarn.

On the basis of the microscopic observations, following assumptions have been made in the topological analysis of 3D five-directional braided composites:
The braiding yarns have a uniform cross-section shape along the yarn axis while the axial yarns have a variable cross-section shape.
The cross-section shape of the braiding yarn is idealized as hexagon with major and minor axis, f and b, respectively, as shown in Figure 6. Where θ is the apex angle of the hexagon.
The yarn packing factor of the braiding yarn and the axial yarn is equivalent based on Figure 5.
The contact surfaces between the adjacent yarns are tangent.
The cross-section shape of the axial yarn is variable along its axis, as shown in Figure 4.
Figure 6.
Cross-section of braiding yarn.

Although the cross-section shape of the braiding yarn looks more like a ellipse, it is assumed to be a hexagon in our work as other authors have done. This assumption is quite idealized but is very necessary to mesh the geometrical model for FEA. If the cross-section shape of the braiding yarn is assumed to be elliptical, the braiding yarns will touch with each other at a point. In this case, there is a huge difficulty in meshing the geometrical model. However by using the assumption of the hexagonal shape, the tangency between the adjacent braiding yarns is a plane, so the geometrical model can be auto-meshed easily.

Based on the observations of the microstructure as shown in Figure 4, the cross-sections of axial yarns are variable in different cutting planes. For simplicity, cross-section shape of the axial yarn is treated as square at the start cutting plane as shown in Figure 7. The side length of the square is equal to (e+b/2). According to the braiding process, the braiding yarns with same oriented major axis of the cross-section are moved in the opposite directions, thus the cross-section of the axial yarn is changed accordingly. From Figure 7(a)–(d), the cross-section shape of the axial yarn is extruded when one braiding yarn pushes in and another braiding yarn withdraws. Since both of the coupled braiding yarns move same distance in the opposite directions, the cross-section area of the axial yarn keeps constant along its axial direction. According to Figure 7(a), the cross-section area of the axial yarn is given by: (2) Figure 7.
Cross-section of axial yarn in the model.
And the section area of the braiding yarn can be written as: (3)

The side length of the cross-section of the axial yarn is defined as rb to compare with the previous model,15 where r is the size factor of the axial yarn, and r, then Equations (2) and (3) can be rewritten as follows: (4) (5)
Considering the yarn linear density ρ and the fiber density λ, the cross-section area of the yarn is obtained by: (6) Where, ε is the yarn packing factor.
The ratio of the yarn packing factor between the axial yarn and the braiding yarn can be expressed as: (7)

In the new model, the value of εa/εb equals 1 and is in accordance with the observations of the microstructure as shown in Figure 5. Given interior braiding angle, the value of r can be derived by Equation (7). Then the fiber volume fraction of the unit cell can be obtained: (8)

Figure 8 shows the variation of the yarn packing factor vs. the interior braiding angle and the fiber-volume fraction. The yarn packing factor decreases with the braiding angle increases, and increases as the fiber volume fraction increases. Compared with the results of existing model (Figure 2), the value of yarn packing factor is in a reasonable region. Figure 8.
Variations of the yarn packing factor versus the interior braiding angle in present model.

According to Figure 4, the cross-section shape of the axial yarn is deformed caused by the compress of adjacent braiding yarns in different directions. A solid model of the axial yarn is presented in Figure 9. It shows that the cross-section shape of the axial yarn changes periodically along its axial direction, which is good agreement with the results described in literature.14 Figure 9.
Axial yarn in present study.

sec.title: Finite element model
sec.p:
Transversely isotropic material properties are assigned to the yarns and isotropic properties to the matrix. The yarns contain thousands of fibers and can be regarded as unidirectional fiber-reinforced composites, which are assumed to be transversely isotropic materials in each local material coordinate system. The resin matrix is assumed to be isotropic material. The engineering elastic constants of the yarns can be calculated by the micromechanics formulae proposed by Chamis.21 The material properties used in the in the calculation are listed in Table 1.22 Table 1.
Material properties
E11 (GPA) E22 (GPA) G12 (GPA) G23 (GPA) ν12 (GPA)
Carbon fiber T300 230 40 24 14.3 0.25
Epoxy TDE-85 3.5
0.25

There are four group braiding yarns and one group axial yarn in the model. The local material coordinate systems 1-2-3 are defined for the braiding yarn and the axial yarn. The principal direction 1 corresponds to the fiber direction and the principal direction 3 is located in the upright 1–3 plane perpendiculars to the x–y plane. It should be noted that the unsymmetrical variation of the axial yarn has been ignored here.

Due to the complexity of the microstructure, solid tetrahedron elements are used to mesh the model under the free mesh option. As shown in Figure 10, the specimen no. 4 in Table 1 is meshed by 58,006 elements. Each element only contains one component material (yarn or matrix); Different materials are shown in the different color. It is emphasized that the tetrahedron elements included in one yarn should be put into the same local material coordinate system, Furthermore, the nodes between the yarn and the resin are merged automatically, which means the perfect interface, and the continuity of displacements at the interface will be satisfied automatically. However, the perfect interface will lead to the predicted results of the elastic modulus a little higher; this problem should be considered in further work. The linear elastic analysis is performed on the FEA model. The strain–stress relation can be written as: (9) Figure 10.
Finite element Mesh of unit cell.
Where, Sij is the effective compliance matrix, ε¯i is the global average strain, and σ¯j is the global average stress.

Assuming a set of the global strain ε¯i, and applying the averaged displacement boundary conditions in the FEA, we can obtain a unique stress distribution of the unit cell. Then the global stress σ¯j, corresponding to this set of global strain, can be deduced by:23 (10)

In the 3D case, six linearly independent sets of global strains ε¯i were applied in the finite element analysis of the unit cell; six equations thus can be obtained. We can calculate the corresponding global stress σ¯j by Equation (10) then. Finally, the effective compliance matrix Sij is given by: (11)

To verify the finite element modeling in this study, four kinds of samples with different braiding parameters were selected, as listed in Table 2. Table 3 gives the comparison between the predicated results and the experimental data. Good agreement is obtained between the predicted results and the available experimental data. The convergence of the mesh sensitivity to the predicted results was also investigated as shown in Figure 11. It shows that the predicted results converge quickly when the element number more than 20,000. Figure 11.
Predicted results versus element number. Table 2.

Figure 12 shows the variation of the predicted elastic modulus with the increasing interior braiding angle with three different fiber-volume fractions. Figure 12(a) presents the axial elastic modulus Ez decreases sharply as the interior braiding angle increases, but increases as the fiber-volume fraction increases. Figure 12(b) describes the variation of transverse elastic modulus Ey with the interior braiding angle under different fiber-volume fractions. With the fiber-volume fraction increasing, the transverse elastic modulus Ey of 3D five-directional braided composites increases obviously. However, it almost remains constant with the interior braiding angle increasing, this is different from the existing model (Xu, 2008; Li, 2008) and should be validated in further experiments. The biggest advantage of present model is capable of predicting the elastic properties of 3D five-directional braided composites with high fiber-volume fraction (more than 50%). Figure 12.
Predicted effective elastic modulus against the fiber-volume fraction and interior braiding angle.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An internal unit cell model of 3D braided composites with a dense but non-intersecting geometry is developed based on the microscopic observations of the cross-section and the yarn arrangement. Microscopic evidences reveal that the cross-section of the axial yarn deforms along its centerline due to the lateral compression of adjacent braiding yarns in different direction. Series images of cross-sections of the unit cell are used to compare with experimental results to validate the accuracy of the microstructure model. New relationship between the microstructure parameters and the yarn pack factor is established to insure the yarn pack factor in a reasonable region.

According to the novel unit model, a 3D mesomechanical FEA is proposed to predict the effective elastic properties and the mesoscale mechanical behaviors of 3D five-directional braided composites. Comparison between the predicted results and the available experimental data demonstrates that the present model can predict the elastic properties of 3D five-directional braided composites with fiber volume fraction over 50%.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by Tianjin Municipal Science and Technology Commission [grant number NO.08JCZDJC24400], the Ministry of Education [grant number NO.NECT-05-0254], and National Natural Science Foundation of China [grant number NO.11072175/A020305].
